Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2008 04:51PM frangaydos wrote: Skye, I would get a second opinion if I were you.  I don't mean to alarm you, but there is a breast cancer called inflammatory breast cancer that presents itself with itchiness, pain and swelling and is often misdiagnosed as a rash or a bug bite.  Regardless, your symptoms need to be looked at.  Is there a Breast Center near you?  These are centers that go from mammogram to ultra-sound to biopsy without delays in between. Fran
Posts.Title: Just need to vent Cessairskye leaf

Posts.Content: frangaydos wrote: After a re-call for more mammogram images (the digital mammograms showed a small area of concern), then an ultra-sound that showed nothing, I was asked to have a BSGI test, which I was told would be definitive for cancer or not.  Now I've been asked to do a biopsy because the BSGI test showed radioactive uptake in a very small area that was not clearly circumscribed.  What does that result mean - a cancerous lesion or they still need more testing?  Do other things than cancer take-up the radioactivity? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: BSGI tests frangaydos ajwgis

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 03:39PM frangaydos wrote: For those of you reading my earlier post, I have since found out that radioactive "hotspots" that show up on any Breast Specific Gamma Imaging test are not always cancer.  There are several benign conditiions that can cause "hotspots."  I did ultimately have a biopsy, which thankfully was benign.  I have fibrocystic disease, i.e., lumpy breasts, one of the benign conditions that can show up as a "hotspot."  I think that the BSGI test is just another needed new test in the breast screening arsenal, but a biopsy is the only way to know for sure what something is.
Posts.Title: BSGI tests frangaydos ajwgis

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 02:03PM frangaydos wrote: The Breast Specific Gamma Imaging test is done by an injection in the arm of a small amount of radioactive tracer, then the breasts are viewed on a special machine with views lasting for two 20 min. sessions on each breast.  The machine is similiar to a mammogram, but the compression is not necessary, and the test is done while you are seated.  The machine looks for radioactive hotspots that would suggest increased cell activity, which might mean cancer cells, but as I said before, there are a number of benign conditions like mine, fibrocystic disease, that can produce hotspots also.  It is meant to be a screening device....if no hotspots show up, then the likelihood of cancer would be slim.
Posts.Title: BSGI tests frangaydos ajwgis
